title: Will Iraq hold parliamentary elections before 1 December 2020?
preds:
Iraq PM facing off attempts to obstruct early elections - Middle East Monitor
https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20201117-iraq-pm-facing-off-attempts-to-obstruct-early-elections/
Tue, 17 Nov 2020 12:27:00 GMT Probability below 0% now. :-)

Iraqi parliament votes on final version of electoral law - Al-Monitor
https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/11/iraq-elections-law-parliament.html
Mon, 02 Nov 2020 21:06:07 GMT >Iraq's Council of Representatives voted on the electoral law, which, if passed, will put forward the program for early elections scheduled for next June.

Iraq is preoccupied by a severe economic turndown due to Covid-19 and the Oil price.
All indications point to a June 2021 election. https://epc.ae/whatif-details/27/will-iraq-really-see-early-elections  https://news.cgtn.com/news/2020-08-01/Iraq-PM-calls-early-election-for-June-6-2021-SAKI3p0P8k/index.html

From 2005-2018, there have been 4 (2005, 2010, 2014, 2018) Iraqi parliamentary elections ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Iraqi_parliamentary_election X = Parliamentary Elections will take place in Iraq before December 2020
X = 29% = 4 / (2018 - 2005 + 1) Given there are only 3 months remaining before December 2020 ->
7% = 3/12 * 29% Additionally with COVID-19, seems highly unlikely that a parliamentary election could be conducted safely ->
4% = 0.5 * 7%
Looks like early elections won’t take place until June 2021

As of May 2020. The various factions are not agreement as to the Electoral law and the methods of representation by changing from proportional representation to individual selection and also to avoid the accusation of vote rigging in the last election where there are calls to handle corruption issues before a new election may be set.
Due to the slump in the Oil Price, Iraq’s main source (90%) of  government revenue has diminished (65% of GDP) and the onset of coronavirus has exacerbated the economic situation with the addition of terrorism form Islamic State (IS). Unemployment is rife and public services lacking suggesting that structural issues have to be confronted before divisive elections should be held.
The country does not have its constitution in place to to hold elections and the country can ill-afford to hold them now. Even though Al-Kadhimi has announced early elections to be his top priority, his government will have to address the economic problems before the country considers a new administration. https://epc.ae/topic/the-electoral-law-the-high-commission-and-the-federal-court-a-trilateral-threat-to-the-next-iraqi-elections  https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/oil-and-gas-after-covid-19-the-day-of-reckoning-or-a-new-age-of-opportunity#  https://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2020/0427/How-the-oil-crash-affects-oil-dependent-countries-like-Iraq  http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-06/09/c_139124319.htm  https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20200624-pm-iraq-to-hold-early-parliamentary-elections/  https://warontherocks.com/2020/05/keep-expectations-modest-for-iraqs-new-government/  https://reliefweb.int/report/iraq/iraq-unhcr-covid-19-update-xii-12-july-2020https://warontherocks.com/2020/05/keep-expectations-modest-for-iraqs-new-government/  https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/menasource/challenges-for-iraqs-new-government-under-mustafa-al-kadhimi/  https://reliefweb.int/report/iraq/ishm-june-18-25-2020  https://www.rudaw.net/english/analysis/28062020  https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-52571220  https://www.washingtoninstitute.org/fikraforum/view/Iraq-Kadhimi-government-parliament-prime-minister  https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/new-atlanticist/after-months-of-gridlock-iraq-gets-a-new-government/  https://kapita.iq/storage/app/media/Research/Covid19-IRAQ-Research.pdf  https://english.aawsat.com//home/article/2165726/iraq-parliament-must-decide-holding-early-elections
Update for passing time. Reducing time spent for forecasting for a while.

Holding elections would not be prudent in 2020 due to Covid-19 and is therefore even more of a  long shot than before.
https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/iraq/

No date mentioned. Most likely in 2021. If 4 million civil servants do not get paid there may be a revolt long before that. https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20200624-pm-iraq-to-hold-early-parliamentary-elections/
Here is an interesting link.
Due to Covid-19 and lack of technology platforms to support ballot counts etc it is unlikely that elections will take place this year.
Looks like the only way is down...

Latest news I found:
https://morningstaronline.co.uk/article/w/iraqi-communists-demand-early-elections Doesn´t look good for elections before 1 December. Going down slightly from 9 to 7%.

https://thearabweekly.com/iraqi-pm-pledges-protect-protesters-hold-elections-soon-possible
https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/05/iraq-kadimi-protests.html
Raising on the slim chance Kadimi can pull off an early election but there are many factions so more likely chaos will reign until some strongman leader comes along and is able to put all rebellion down. Hate to see that model of government but do not see unarmed protesters overcoming all the armed factions in the country.

Lowering 63%. I guess I was fooled by the Prime Minister's declarations.
https://www.almaalomah.com/2020/05/20/475068/

Going further down, reason:  "On the first count, the prime minister has promised  “early” elections as part of his program. This will be very difficult to make happen in any real sense. Setting up elections in Iraq is a slow and onerous process at any time, and the reality of COVID-19 adds a further degree of difficulty. Nonetheless, the prime minister should attempt to schedule elections for November or December of 2021 (they would normally be expected between April and July of 2022). This date has the virtue of a) giving the government time to prepare, b) costing the existing power structure little, by leaving power only four-six months early, and c) giving a small win to the protesters, who can truthfully say they pushed elections into the preceding year. There are many important details still to be ironed out in the election law and political parties law that codify the election; close watch should be kept by major international organizations. No existing power brokers, in any country, will meekly agree to electoral rules changes that do not work to their advantage." From:
https://warontherocks.com/2020/05/keep-expectations-modest-for-iraqs-new-government/

At least they´ve got a government now. 7 months left for a parliamentary election. Not much time, especially in times of crisis.  https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/05/iraq-vote-parliament-kadhimi-government-economy.html

Going down big. 
Only 7 months left. Problems to form a government, everybody disagrees with everyone in parliament, Corona as an excuse to do nothing for a while (and to suppress prostest perhaps), lowest oil price ever (oil sector provides roughly 85% of government revenue and 80% of foreign exchange earnings) so huge economic problems to be expected. A date would need to be set soon to realistically have an election befor 1 Dec.. Nothing about it in the media (at least I haven´t found anything). 
Under these actual circumstances I don´t think, it will happen in time for this question.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iraq-politics/iraq-names-its-third-prime-minister-in-10-weeks-idUSKCN21R18Z?il=0 Sooner or later everyone in the country will have been PM For A Day and there will have to be something very like elections.  I think everyone will not yet have had a turn by December, and elections can be more disruptive than having no government, depending.  I do wish I felt more certain about this number.

The current nominations will take place until a minimum of next Thursday. Likely longer. It is likely that there will be a few more that try to secure the PM position if Zurfi is unsuccessful, however he still has a good chance. 
If Zurfi gains the support which I think it’s a 60% chance, elections will happen within a year or the date of support. Which will be mid 2021.
All this x Covid, it isn’t happening this year.  I’m going big on this one.  https://www.thenational.ae/world/mena/political-factions-may-block-iraq-s-al-zurfi-from-forming-government-officials-say-1.1003076

They can not even get a current government organized. Parliamentary elections are slated for 2022. Protests under current conditions have waned. If they return later in year probably still no early elections till next year. So many factions! https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/03/iraq-adnan-zurfi-prime-minister.html

The speaker has Covid, Parliament likely to be suspended. 
The Gov would want 2 months to plan, promote an election. They would want to ensure they are free (Past comments). 
Will an election be announced in the next 6 months (would be needed to take place before 1/12)? 
Unlikely considering the country will likely be social distancing for the next few months. Planned elections all over the world are being cancelled. Are countries really going to call early ones?  Thoughts?

2 reasons for the drop.  - time 
- the new prime minister has pledged an election within 1 year. Not imminently. I would expect an election In the first or 2nd quarter of next year  https://www.tv7israelnews.com/iraqs-incumbent-prime-minister-pledges-fair-elections-within-one-year/

https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2020/03/20/iraq-has-a-new-prime-minister-what-next/ And then there´s corona (which will hit them hard). Preliminary new elections under those conditions? I don´t think so...

The article below outlines the detail of oil prices and the wider implications.
Iraq are the worst country impacted by the oil as per article. 
This insight has means increasing  the chance of elections by 2%  https://www.ecfr.eu/article/commentary_game_of_chicken_how_the_oil_price_war_threatens_the_gulf

Iraq has recently named a new PM, which takes 10% away (38%)
New PM pledges elections within the next 12 months. - They would require at least 8 weeks to hold elections after planned. Will they announce elections within 6 months is now the question. + 5% = 42%

https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/03/iraq-us-pmu-president.html
https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/03/iraq-protests-elections.html
https://www.rudaw.net/english/middleeast/iraq/140320201
The chaos in government, fizzle if protest movement and ramping up of more armed conflict all argue against being able to organize this by then.
The caretaker PM has recently called for elections. There are still many barriers in place. Slight increase
This will depend on how the insurrection plays out. The Shias seem to be making a move.
Climbing down from 95. Kleptocrats seem to be playing for time.

They are what is needed so people will continue to push. Holding elections in Iraq, particular early elections are difficult. There are two ways to trigger an early election in Iraq, a 2/3rds vote which would require the Kurds and Sunnis to sign up, which wont happen. The second is to suspend parliament and request the President to call an election - given the debacle that came with suspending parliament last year, the president will be reluctant to do so.
The president could cave and the country is always susceptible to corruption, meaning anything is likely. I lean towards no due to the difficult legislative process.
Good article on why they seem unlikely: https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/02/iraq-early-elections-protests.html

Did not track well. Past my bedtime :-) Indeed it was an article on Iran not Iraq. This article seems moe accurate. https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/02/iraq-elections-law-parliament.html
PM promises early elections but that is a tall order. https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2020-02-19/iraqi-pm-designate-says-done-picking-cabinet-calls-on-parliament-to-approve-it

The new Iraqi PM wants a confidence vote held on the 24th(1), and wants his cabinet approved March 2nd. His first act will not be to call elections but " to investigate the killing of protesters and bring the perpetrators to justice." As it seems to be the security forces who have been killing the protestors(2), we should not rule out the potential for a military coup, or significant further civil disruption. My initial thinking on this was that the parliament will try to not dissolve itself as the new law called for in december will reduce the current parties power and Iraq is a corrupt country. They have added an amendmum to the december law which passed in january which would complicate the passing as it again sets off a power struggle. (3) I am going to increase my forecast for now but in newly democratic countries with poor institutions things often don't go as planned. 1. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iraq-protests/iraqi-pm-designate-says-he-has-picked-cabinet-seeks-vote-of-confidence-idUSKBN20D1GZ 2. https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2020/01/iraq-protest-death-toll-surges-as-security-forces-resume-brutal-repression/ 3. https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/02/iraq-elections-law-parliament.html

Protesters have been demanding new elections.  But Parliament has reportedly avoided responding "because reforms and new elections would likely mean that many established political groups would lose power.:  But the country’s senior religious leaders have sided with the protesters to demand change and their pressure led the prime minister to resign at the end of November. A new primer minister was appointed last week, M. Allawi, NYT reports the choice "it's an effort to pick someone who has worked with a wide range of political parties and who is educated and secular as well as having the requisite Shiite Muslim background" but he comes in with a clout of being weak politically and not a strange himself to corruption. We'll have to see how long he lasts (he has 30 days to form a new government). https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/01/world/middleeast/iraq-names-new-prime-minister-who-praises-bravery-of-protesters.html
The new PM buys a little time, as does the distraction of anti-US protests https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-02-02/new-iraq-pm-appeals-to-the-masses-but-is-rejected-by-protesters/11921700
I´m very sceptical for Iraq and the whole Region concerning any Kind of democracy. Elections aren´t to the iraqis what they are to us. Could be a lot of wishful thinking even in this estimate.

At the end of December Sistani called for early elections. He carry’s a lot of weight there. Youth are protesting and asking for early elections. Those in government may not want them. Raising. https://twitter.com/eng_ali_atabey/status/1219072640494850055?s=21

'As a result of the ongoing 2019 Iraqi protests, the Council of Representatives approved a new law on 24 December 2019 which aims to make it easier for independent politicians to win a seat in the Council of Representatives. The new law will see each of Iraq's governorates split into several electoral districts, with one legislator being elected per 100,000 people, thus replacing its proportional representation system for a district-based system. The new law will also prevent parties from running on unified list'
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Council_of_Representatives_of_Iraq#2019_electoral_reform
Iraq wants to wait out the U S election to see where things lie. Too much uncertainty there already. This is one thing in their control.
They might be announced before December 2020 but I don't think they'll take place this calendar year.
There are too many factions that have too many agendas.  The recent crisis with Iran has ramped up the unrest, yet there is no one direction or party who benefits from it.
Increasing after re-evaluating the time frame
Lowering. Mahdi is only in caretaker role. Chaos in the country again so not sure any cohedive action can be taken. May lower more.

Law passed in December. Protests and the need to show it is a viable country means they need to have them. If, however, the sectarian/ethnic split gets worse then civil war or a break-up of country is more likely. https://apnews.com/e608aeef311759aeeb7483ad3f9f33d5

'Early elections look unlikely, however, because the law is silent on how electoral districts will be formed or who will designate them. Figuring out how that will work could take months or longer, said Tariq Harb, an expert on the Iraqi Constitution and legal system.'
- https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/24/world/middleeast/iraq-election-law.html
Shifting much higher because the government has now passed a new electoral law. I think that makes an election much more likely but I'm waiting to go higher until there is a new prime minister.
Maybe we should ask how many Iraq;s will there be by Dec 31st 2020. If the Kurds get independence they other two sides can unite. Not til then i do not think.

https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2019/12/iraq-parliament-reform-electoral-commission.html December 27, 2019 First 3 paragraphs: "BAGHDAD — Amid preparations for early elections in Iraq, the parliamentary blocs are trying to meet the demands of the popular protests that began over two months ago. Protesters have demanded a new political system, but Iraqi politicians have not been able to find adequate solutions. Parliament approved a new law related to the Independent High Electoral Commission (IHEC) Dec. 5, yet popular and official criticism of the law continues. The law states that “IHEC members shall be seven experienced judges who will be chosen by a draw to ensure transparency.” However, granting the judiciary in the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) the right to nominate two judges raised the ire of many protesters and some political parties. They perceived this as an attempt to evade their calls for an end to the sectarian and national quota in the country. Also, the method by which a draw may be conducted is still unresolved. Fears remain that some influential parties might tamper with the IHEC and interfere with the nomination process... "

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/12/iraq-shia-leader-calls-early-election-unrest-protests-191220095956899.html December 20, 2019 First 3 paragraphs: "Iraq's top Shia leader Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani has said an early election resulting in a new government was the only way out of the current unrest gripping the country. More than 450 people, mostly unarmed demonstrators but also some members of the security forces, have been killed since a wave of popular anti-government unrest began on October 1. "The fastest and most peaceful way out of the current crisis, and avoiding the unknown or chaos or civil strife, is to go back to the people by holding an early election after legislating a fair electoral law," al-Sistani said in a speech read out by a representative at a Friday sermon in the Shia holy city of Karbala."

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/12/iraqi-parliament-approves-electoral-law-deadlock-persists-191224151656941.html First 3 paragraphs: "Iraq's parliament has approved a new electoral law, a key demand of protesters to make elections fairer, but political deadlock is still holding up the selection of an interim prime minister. Mass protests have gripped Iraq since October 1 and protesters, most of them young, are demanding an overhaul of a political system they see as profoundly corrupt and keeping most Iraqis in poverty. More than 450 people have been killed. The new election law passed by parliament on Tuesday will allow voters to elect individual legislators instead of choosing from party lists, and have each member of parliament represent a specific electoral district instead of groups of legislators representing entire provinces....."
Iraq is very volatile at the moment and seemingly getting more so. An election may held the government appease the population or indeed be forced upon them
Hard to imagine elections not occurring given current level of unrest.

The Iraqi youth are completely dissatisfied with the current political system based on muhasasa ta'ifa - sectarian based appointment.  Following his request to step down as prime minister, Abdul-Mahdi and his government are acting as a caretaker government, until a new prime minister is appointed. According to the Iraqi constitution the Iraqi president will give the largest block in the parliament the chance to nominate a new prime minister. Muqtdada al-Sadr from the Saairun block mentioned that they would be interested in having a referendum with five prime minister candidates. It is doubtful though, that simply replacing the prime minister and government will calm the protesters, who want to abolish the current muhasasa ta'ifa political system, and moreover, transfer the country from a parliamentarian system to a presidential one. It can be expected that the members of the current parliament will fight tooth and nail not to give up their privileged positions, but with enough pressure from the public, and perhaps another statement from Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, they too would remove themselves from power.

"Article 64:
First: The Council of Representatives may be dissolved by an absolute majority of the number of its members, or upon the request of one-third of its members by the
Prime Minister with the consent of the President of the Republic. The Council shall not be dissolved during the period in which the Prime Minister is being questioned. Second: Upon the dissolution of the Council of Representatives, the President of the Republic shall call for general elections in the country within a period not to
exceed sixty days from the date of its dissolution. The Council of Ministers in this case is deemed resigned and continues to run everyday business."(1) Adil Abdul-Mahdi will remain in his post as a caretaker until a new prime minister is appointed "the president is expected to ask the largest bloc in parliament to nominate a new prime minister to form a government."(2) It took 5 months for the coalition to be formed and Adil Abdul-Mahdi to become prime minister in 2018, so although the largest bloc will be asked there could be new negotiations within the Council of Representatives (the Iraqi Parliament). If one is appointed without protracted negotiations, then the base rate for a new Iraqi prime minister is 3 years (since 2004). The next Iraqi parliamentary elections are due in 2022. I am not sure that the Iraqi Parliament will dissolve itself given the need for a majority when it can appoint a prime minister. Another scenario which would mean no parliamentary elections would be there could be a state of emergency declared if civil unrest continues. (3) 1. Constitution of Iraq
2. https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-50619997
3. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/nov/30/iraq-risks-breakup-blood-fued-protests-iran-influence

Over the last decade and a half, the Iraqi parliamentary election has been consistently held once every, ~4 years  (except in 2005 when two elections were held due to the change in the constitution). For the constitution to change, there are a myriad of activities required: drafting of the amendment (which could take as much as 7 months), the public acquiescing to the change via a referendum, etc.    Only after the constitution has been successfully changed can there be a new parliamentary election. ~One year, Nov.  2019 - Dec 2020 is a relatively tight time frame.

Iraqi prime minister resigning in face of (continuing) protests.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/nov/29/iraq-pm-resign-protests-abdul-mahdi-al-sistani

Iraqi Prime Minister may be attempting to buy time in order to find a suitable way to quiet the protesters. https://www-washingtonpost-com.cdn.ampproject.org/v/s/www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/iraqs-president-promises-new-elections-law-and-early-polls-amid-protests/2019/10/31/c2676e4a-fbea-11e9-9534-e0dbcc9f5683_story.html?amp_js_v=a2&amp_gsa=1&usqp=mq331AQCKAE%3D#aoh=15747460582355&referrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com&amp_tf=From%20%251%24s&ampshare=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.washingtonpost.com%2Fworld%2Fmiddle_east%2Firaqs-president-promises-new-elections-law-and-early-polls-amid-protests%2F2019%2F10%2F31%2Fc2676e4a-fbea-11e9-9534-e0dbcc9f5683_story.html

Iraqi Prime Minister may be attempting to buy time in order to find a suitable way to quiet the protesters. https://www-washingtonpost-com.cdn.ampproject.org/v/s/www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/iraqs-president-promises-new-elections-law-and-early-polls-amid-protests/2019/10/31/c2676e4a-fbea-11e9-9534-e0dbcc9f5683_story.html?amp_js_v=a2&amp_gsa=1&usqp=mq331AQCKAE%3D#aoh=15747460582355&referrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com&amp_tf=From%20%251%24s&ampshare=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.washingtonpost.com%2Fworld%2Fmiddle_east%2Firaqs-president-promises-new-elections-law-and-early-polls-amid-protests%2F2019%2F10%2F31%2Fc2676e4a-fbea-11e9-9534-e0dbcc9f5683_story.html
I'll go up a lot once a new election law is passed but I'm not sure when or how that will happen.

https://www.kurdistan24.net/en/news/80728bf3-eb95-4e76-a30f-345cf9a48d3c (June 17-2019) Elections already have been postponed twice. Article states "It is still unclear whether the voting will take place in all provinces across Iraq, especially those that are still struggling to return displaced residents and rebuild infrastructure."  Still think its on track for April 2020 +/- a few months but hitting the December 2020 deadline.

The current government will not weather the current crisis.  Moving around the participants in the current government will not satisfy the demands of the street nor solve the problems.  An election may not either but it will be done in an attempted solution.
